items.text: **Michael Kenneth Williams** (born November 22, 1966) is an American actor, dancer, and reporter.

He is best known for his portrayal of [[LINK|lang_en|Omar_Little|Omar Little]] on the [[LINK|lang_en|HBO|HBO]] drama series *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Wire|The Wire]] * [[CITE|34|https://usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-05-26-tv-mvps_x.htm]] [[CITE|3|http://slantmagazine.com/dvd/dvd_review.asp?ID=481]] [[CITE|9|http://cpgo.citypaper.com/film/story.asp?id=9538]] and Albert "Chalky" White on the HBO series *[[LINK|lang_en|Boardwalk_Empire|Boardwalk Empire]] *. He was also acclaimed for his role as Jack Gee, husband of [[LINK|lang_en|Bessie_Smith|Bessie Smith]], in the HBO [[LINK|lang_en|Television_film|telefilm]] [[LINK|lang_en|Biographical_film|biopic]] *[[LINK|lang_en|Bessie_(film)|Bessie]] *. He has acted in supporting roles in a number of films and television series, including *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Road_(2009_film)|The Road]] *, *[[LINK|lang_en|Inherent_Vice_(film)|Inherent Vice]] *, *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Night_Of|The Night Of]] *, *[[LINK|lang_en|Gone_Baby_Gone|Gone Baby Gone]] *, and *[[LINK|lang_en|12_Years_a_Slave_(film)|12 Years a Slave]] *.
Early life and education

Born in [[LINK|lang_en|Brooklyn|Brooklyn]], to an [[LINK|lang_en|African_American|African American]] father from [[LINK|lang_en|South_Carolina|South Carolina]] and a [[LINK|lang_en|Bahamian_people|Bahamian]] mother from [[LINK|lang_en|Nassau,_Bahamas|Nassau]], Williams was raised in the Vanderveer Apartments in [[LINK|lang_en|East_Flatbush,_Brooklyn|East Flatbush]], [[LINK|lang_en|Brooklyn|Brooklyn]], [[LINK|lang_en|New_York_City|New York City]], [[CITE|14|http://nypost.com/2013/10/19/michael-k-williams-my-brooklyn]] [[CITE|18|http://vibe.com/article/michael-k-williams-snitch-life-after-the-wire-acting-advice-2-pac]] and attended [[LINK|lang_en|George_Westinghouse_Career_and_Technical_Education_High_School|George Westinghouse Career and Technical Education High School]]. [[CITE|20|http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/62355]] According to a DNA analysis, he is descended partly from the [[LINK|lang_en|Mende_people|Mende people]] of [[LINK|lang_en|Sierra_Leone|Sierra Leone]]. [[CITE|24|http://okayplayer.com/news/michael-k-williams-african-ancestry-video.html]]
After getting in some trouble as a youth, he enrolled at the [[LINK|lang_en|National_Black_Theatre|National Black Theatre]] in New York City.
Career
Williams worked for a pharmaceutical company.

However, inspired by *[[LINK|lang_en|Janet_Jackson's_Rhythm_Nation_1814|Janet Jackson's Rhythm Nation 1814]] *, he left school and quit his job, against the wishes of his family, to pursue a career as a dancer. During a year in which he was intermittently homeless, Williams visited record labels and dance studios looking for work. He got a job as a background dancer on a music tour for [[LINK|lang_en|Kym_Sims|Kym Sims]]' dance anthem *Too Blind To See It*, which led to more work appearing as a dancer in videos and on tours, such as with [[LINK|lang_en|George_Michael|George Michael]], [[LINK|lang_en|Madonna_(entertainer)|Madonna]], as well as some modeling work. He also choreographed [[LINK|lang_en|Crystal_Waters|Crystal Waters]]' 1994 single "[[LINK|lang_en|100%_Pure_Love|100% Pure Love]]". [[CITE|27|http://npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=18299087]] [[CITE|31|http://wbez.org/blog/justin-kaufmann/2011-09-23/wikipedia-files-michael-k-williams-omar-wire-92391]]

He was given one of his first acting roles after being discovered by [[LINK|lang_en|Tupac_Shakur|Tupac Shakur]] and was cast as High Top, the brother and henchman to Shakur's drug kingpin Tank, in the 1996 film *[[LINK|lang_en|Bullet_(1996_film)|Bullet]] *. [[CITE|35|http://page-31.com/article.php?Michael-K-Williams-discusses-being-discovered-by-Tupac%2F1088=]]

Williams is well known for a large facial scar received during a bar fight on [[LINK|lang_en|Jamaica_Avenue|Jamaica Avenue]], New York City, on his 25th birthday, in which he was slashed with a [[LINK|lang_en|Razor|razor]] blade. [[CITE|1|http://time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1942833,00.html]] The scar became his signature feature, and resulted in offers to perform as a thug in music videos [[CITE|1|http://time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1942833,00.html]] and modeling opportunities with noted photographers like [[LINK|lang_en|David_LaChapelle|David LaChapelle]].

Michael K. Williams also serves as the [[LINK|lang_en|American_Civil_Liberties_Union|American Civil Liberties Union]] celebrity ambassador to the Campaign for Smart Justice. [[CITE|5|https://aclu.org/ambassadors]]
*The Wire*

Williams is known for his portrayal of [[LINK|lang_en|Omar_Little|Omar Little]] in *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Wire|The Wire]],* which began filming in 2002. The character was based on [[LINK|lang_en|Donnie_Andrews|Donnie Andrews]], as well as other crime figures in Baltimore. [[CITE|8|http://baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/crime/blog/bal-donnie-andrews-inspiration-for-omar-character-on-the-wire-dies-20121214,0,3207915.story]] Williams received the part after only a single audition. [[CITE|10|http://hobotrashcan.com/interviews/michaelkwilliams.php]] He was initially told that the character was slated to appear in just seven episodes of the first season and feared that the character would be killed before the end of the season. [[CITE|10|http://hobotrashcan.com/interviews/michaelkwilliams.php]] However, creator [[LINK|lang_en|David_Simon_(writer)|David Simon]] stated that they always planned to keep the character as part of the continuing ensemble should the show be renewed beyond the first season.

For his portrayal of Omar, Williams was named by *[[LINK|lang_en|USA_Today|USA Today]] * as one of ten reasons they still love television. Omar was praised for his uniqueness in the stale landscape of TV crime dramas and for the wit and humor that Williams brings to the portrayal. [[CITE|34|https://usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-05-26-tv-mvps_x.htm]] Omar has been named as one of the first season's richest characters, a [[LINK|lang_en|Robin_Hood|Robin Hood]] of Baltimore's west side projects. The *[[LINK|lang_en|Baltimore_City_Paper|Baltimore City Paper]] * named the character one of their top ten reasons not to cancel the show and called him "arguably the showâ€™s single greatest achievement". [[CITE|9|http://cpgo.citypaper.com/film/story.asp?id=9538]] In 2007 he was nominated for an NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Actor in a Drama Series for his role as Omar. [[CITE|16|http://hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/features/e3i1df4dfd4706f9fc31fefc3974392be1d]]
Williams pursued the role because he was intrigued by Omar's contradictory nature.
[[CITE|10|http://hobotrashcan.com/interviews/michaelkwilliams.php]] He felt Omar's popularity stemmed from his honesty, lack of materialism, individuality and his adherence to his strict code.
[[CITE|10|http://hobotrashcan.com/interviews/michaelkwilliams.php]] He feels that the role has been a breakthrough in terms of bringing attention to him and getting further roles.

[[CITE|23|http://afterelton.com/archive/elton/people/2006/9/williams2.html]] Williams has received both positive and negative reactions to Omar's homosexuality and feels that he is successful in challenging attitudes and provoking discussion with the role.
[[CITE|23|http://afterelton.com/archive/elton/people/2006/9/williams2.html]]
In 2008, then-U.S.

Senator [[LINK|lang_en|Barack_Obama|Barack Obama]] cited *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Wire|The Wire]] * as his favorite television show, and called Omar his favorite character. About Omar, Obama said, "Thatâ€™s not an endorsement. He's not my favorite person, but he's a fascinating character... he's the toughest, baddest guy on the show." [[CITE|29|http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2008/01/barack-obama-on.html]]

During his portrayal of Omar Little, Williams went by his character's name and developed a habit of smoking [[LINK|lang_en|Cannabis|cannabis]] and an addiction to [[LINK|lang_en|Cocaine|cocaine]] in 2004. [[CITE|32|http://huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/04/michael-k-williams-cocaine_n_1854966.html]] [[CITE|36|http://nj.com/inside-jersey/index.ssf/2012/08/the_redemption_of_michael_k_williams.html]]
Other work

Williams had a recurring role on [[LINK|lang_en|J._J._Abrams|J. J. Abrams]]'*[[LINK|lang_en|Alias_(TV_series)|Alias]] *. He also had a recurring role on Abrams' produced *Six Degrees*. [[CITE|23|http://afterelton.com/archive/elton/people/2006/9/williams2.html]] He has also made brief appearances on *[[LINK|lang_en|CSI:_Crime_Scene_Investigation|CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]] * (playing two different characters on two different seasons), *[[LINK|lang_en|Boston_Legal|Boston Legal]] *, *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Sopranos|The Sopranos]] *, *[[LINK|lang_en|Law_&_Order|Law & Order]] * (playing three different characters on three different seasons), *[[LINK|lang_en|Law_&_Order:_Special_Victims_Unit|Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]] * (also playing two different characters on two different seasons), *[[LINK|lang_en|Human_Giant|Human Giant]] * and *[[LINK|lang_en|Third_Watch|Third Watch]] *.

Williams makes a brief appearance as the shooter at the beginning of the music video for [[LINK|lang_en|Young_Jeezy|Young Jeezy]]'s "Bury Me a G". He appears in *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Kill_Point|The Kill Point]] * as recurring guest star Q, a police sniper, alongside *The Wire* co-stars [[LINK|lang_en|J._D._Williams|J. D. Williams]], [[LINK|lang_en|Michael_Hyatt|Michael Hyatt]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Leo_Fitzpatrick|Leo Fitzpatrick]]. He auditioned for the starring role of Mr. Cat but was forced to take a smaller role due to scheduling conflicts; the part of Mr. Cat went to J. D. Williams instead. [[CITE|2|http://nj.com/columns/ledger/sepinwall/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fcolumns-0%2F1187931699223980.xml=&coll=1]] Williams played a Boston area detective named Devin Amronklin in the 2007 film *[[LINK|lang_en|Gone,_Baby,_Gone|Gone, Baby, Gone]] *. The film is based on a novel by [[LINK|lang_en|Dennis_Lehane|Dennis Lehane]], who has written for *The Wire*, and was adapted and directed by [[LINK|lang_en|Ben_Affleck|Ben Affleck]]. Amronklin is a recurring character in Lehane's Kenzie-Genarro series of books. Williams says that he enjoyed working with Affleck and characterized him as a passionate and hands-on director. [[CITE|23|http://afterelton.com/archive/elton/people/2006/9/williams2.html]] The film also featured his co-star from *The Wire*, [[LINK|lang_en|Amy_Ryan|Amy Ryan]].

He played Teddy, the former boyfriend of Nikki Tru ([[LINK|lang_en|Kerry_Washington|Kerry Washington]]) in the [[LINK|lang_en|Chris_Rock|Chris Rock]] film *[[LINK|lang_en|I_Think_I_Love_My_Wife|I Think I Love My Wife]] *. He played James, a policeman, in singer [[LINK|lang_en|R._Kelly|R. Kelly]]'s "[[LINK|lang_en|Trapped_in_the_Closet|Trapped in the Closet]]". He also appeared in [[LINK|lang_en|The_Game_(rapper)|The Game]]'s "Dreams" and "How We Do" music videos, [[LINK|lang_en|Tony_Yayo|Tony Yayo]]'s "It's a Stick Up" music video and [[LINK|lang_en|Cam'ron|Cam'ron]]'s film *[[LINK|lang_en|Killa_Season|Killa Season]] *, as well as [[LINK|lang_en|Trick_Daddy|Trick Daddy]]'s video "Tuck Your Ice In", Sheek Louch's "Good Love", and Young Jeezy's "Bury me a G" alongside his *The Wire* co-star [[LINK|lang_en|Hassan_Johnson|Hassan Johnson]]. In 2013, Williams appeared in ASAP Rocky's video for "Phoenix". [[CITE|4|http://pitchfork.com/news/51679-watch-aap-rockys-phoenix-video-featuring-michael-k-williams-from-the-wire]] Williams played the role of The Thief in the 2009 film *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Road_(2009_film)|The Road]] *, an adaptation of the [[LINK|lang_en|Cormac_McCarthy|Cormac McCarthy]] novel [[LINK|lang_en|The_Road|of the same name]]. [[CITE|7|https://nytimes.com/2008/05/27/movies/27road.html]] In 2010, Williams appeared in the film *[[LINK|lang_en|Life_During_Wartime_(film)|Life During Wartime]] *. The character he played, Allen, was portrayed by [[LINK|lang_en|Philip_Seymour_Hoffman|Philip Seymour Hoffman]] in the film's predecessor, *[[LINK|lang_en|Happiness_(1998_film)|Happiness]] *.

Williams also starred in the film *A Day in the Life*, which was directed, produced and stars rapper [[LINK|lang_en|Sticky_Fingaz|Sticky Fingaz]]. The entire film is a musical with every line being delivered in rap verse. Williams starred in HBO's *[[LINK|lang_en|Boardwalk_Empire|Boardwalk Empire]] * for its five seasons (2010â€“2014). He appeared as Albert "Chalky" White, the leader of 1920s'[[LINK|lang_en|Atlantic_City|Atlantic City]]'s black community.

On July 23, 2011, *[[LINK|lang_en|Community_(TV_series)|Community]] * creator [[LINK|lang_en|Dan_Harmon|Dan Harmon]] revealed that Williams would star in "at least three episodes" of the sitcom's third season. [[CITE|11|http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2011/07/the_wire_star_michael_k_willia.html]] He played the role of Biology Professor [[LINK|lang_en|Marshall_Kane|Marshall Kane]] at Greendale Community College.

In November 2011, it was announced that Williams would appear in [[LINK|lang_en|Quentin_Tarantino|Quentin Tarantino]]'s feature film *[[LINK|lang_en|Django_Unchained|Django Unchained]] *. [[CITE|12|http://deadline.com/2011/11/michael-kenneth-williams-in-talks-for-django-unchained-and-snitch-195801]] Williams, who had previously confirmed that he was actually in talks with Tarantino to take on the titular role of Django, [[CITE|15|http://cinemablend.com/new/Michael-K-Williams-Can-t-Do-Django-Unchained-Has-Role-Snitch-With-Rock-27933.html]] was to portray a minor character in the film, but scheduling conflicts with *Boardwalk Empire* prevented him from doing so.

On May 16, 2012, Williams announced that he was an executive producer of the independent film *[[LINK|lang_en|Snow_on_tha_Bluff|Snow on tha Bluff]] *, Williams' first film under his company, Freedome Productions. On Power 105.1fm's *The Breakfast Club*, Williams revealed the June 19 release date for *Snow on tha Bluff*, describing the movie as "real graphic": "everything that is wrong with the 'hood is in this movie". [[CITE|19|https://youtube.com/watch?v=9O5POPpDcrw%2F]] Williams also shared on *The Breakfast Club* that he was starring in an African American western, *They Die by Dawn*, with his co-star Snoop from the HBO series *The Wire*. Williams also revealed that he was starring in the lead role as rapper [[LINK|lang_en|Ol'_Dirty_Bastard|Ol' Dirty Bastard]] (ODB) from the [[LINK|lang_en|Wu-Tang_Clan|Wu-Tang Clan]] in the movie *Dirty Whiteboy* in 2014, which is based on the relationship ODB had with his manager during the last two years of his life. Williams mentioned the role was special to him because he grew up listening to Ol' Dirty Bastard and to Wu-Tang and he is also a Brooklyn native. [[CITE|19|https://youtube.com/watch?v=9O5POPpDcrw%2F]]
In 2013, he starred in [[LINK|lang_en|MGMT|MGMT]]'s music video for "Cool Song No. 2". [[CITE|25|https://youtube.com/watch?v=Zg2IcEHWXWo%2F]]
Williams was featured modeling for [[LINK|lang_en|Gap_Inc.|The Gap]]'s 2014 fall collection.

On March 9, 2015, it was announced that Williams would star in [[LINK|lang_en|SundanceTV|SundanceTV]]'s *[[LINK|lang_en|Hap_and_Leonard|Hap and Leonard]] *, [[CITE|28|http://sundance.tv/blog/2015/03/michael-k-williams-set-to-star-in-sundancetvs-hap-leonard]] based on a series of novels by [[LINK|lang_en|Joe_R._Lansdale|Joe R. Lansdale]]. The first season got positive reviews and a six-episode season 2 was aired in 2017.
Also in 2015 Williams appeared in the music video for *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Mephistopheles_of_Los_Angeles|The Mephistopheles of Los Angeles]] * by [[LINK|lang_en|Marilyn_Manson|Marilyn Manson]].

Williams has also started working with [[LINK|lang_en|Vice_News|Vice News]] and is hosting a VICELAND television program entitled *[[LINK|lang_en|Black_Market_with_Michael_K._Williams|Black Market]] *. In this series he will be visiting various clandestine markets to explore how they operate while investigating the circumstances that generate their clientele.
